descendants.content: @kegill They are also building and using coal plants like crazy to drive the electric craze, but no one is telling that around...

account.note: www.rejzor.com

descendants.content:
@rejzor @kegill They are decommissioning old non variable plants and building modern efficient variable plants. The new plants can be turned down to almost nothing when there is excess solar. In contrast even the newest Australian coal plant can’t be turned down without it breaking down.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Callide_Power_Station

@Old_IT_geek @rejzor @kegill
Also, when looking at CO2 emissions per capita, China are above France and the UK, on level with Germany, and below Russia and the USA. So I don’t think China can be shamed for using coal, were they to even be listening to outside criticism. Their green strategy is genuine, and nobody else can tell them what to do with it and the wellbeing of its people.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_carbon_dioxide_emissions_per_capita?wprov=sfti1

account.note: Class before ass. I still don’t know what that actually means.

descendants.content:
@kegill

Bit of a contrived way of saying "China installed X Watt-peak of renewable energy generation"

Solar/wind and nuclear are not the same. Renewables generate varying amounts of power and not always in sync with demand.
Nuclear provides power 24x7 regardless of weather patterns.

Also, a nuclear reactor can be anything from some tens of MW to over 1500 MW of electrical power.

China also builds nukes btw 🤷

account.note: Comp/electro/sci nerd | Pro-vaxx, GMOs and peaceful nuke tech | ☢️Amateur radiation det. and physics enthusiast | 📡PD1JMB 📌JO22NB| Utreg | Auti

fields.name: website
fields.value: www.dynode.nl

descendants.content: @dynode @kegill Yes, and neither fits to a varying demand curve and both need to complemented with storage or flexible generation. But renewables are cheap and nuclear is expensive and will make even less sense economically when it can not run 24/7, i.e. in a grid with many renewables.

Well, -something- has to. Either fossil fuels, biomass, nuclear or (currently non-existing) grid-scale storage.

Nuclear can also be modulated, especially newer reactors. For example Olkiluoto 3 in Finland has done so multiple times in response to wind and solar excesses.

descendants.content:
@dynode @uecker @kegill

No one is arguing that the base load is zero. But demand isn't constant (ideal for nuclear) either. Whatever the grid consists of, it needs to handle more generation capacity than demand and more demand than instantaneous generation capacity.

The new Chinese power stations reportedly can ramp up and down generation capacity better than the old power stations.

descendants.content:
@dynode @uecker @kegill

Not sure why batteries need a natural gas power station? Also, China is leading the world on Na-ion batteries (just deployed first grid scale battery) which will help with resources.

But the basic reality of economics: (Solar building out equivalant of 1.5GW generation per fortnight assuming 30% capacity factor) at a far lower price than nuclear. and the price is still dropping.

Nuclear just will not be able to compete economically.

descendants.content:
@Tallish_Tom @dynode @kegill

He meant for flexible generation. We still need flexible generation (and this why China also built new coal plants) for a while. But it is not as bad as nuclear proponents claim - and more importantly - nuclear does not really help here. Germany's gas use for electricity generation did not increase despite a large scale rollout of renewables (and gas use for electricity is a small fraction than used for heating).

descendants.content:
@kegill @Tallish_Tom @dynode I do not understand what you want to say. I agree we still need flexible generation for renewables.

But nuclear is also no solution on its own, because it can not adapt to the demand curve. (It can in theory, but then it is even less competitive economically). So if you believe renewables can not work because you need either storage or additional flexible generation, then the same applies it nuclear (to lesser degree, but still).

descendants.content: @kegill @Tallish_Tom @dynode There is the tendency to dismiss such achievement with renewables by pointing out that they are intermittent, so one additionally needs storage or flexible generation. Then nuclear is brought up as an alternative that does not have the problem. I point out that the later is not true, because 100% nuclear is not feasible, and you would also have to complement them with storage or flexible generation (although to a lesser degree).
